translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Great Advice
“Whatever these various views there are,
All of them argue that ‘this alone is the truth.’
All of them are condemned,
And some of them are praised.”
“But this is little, not enough for the time:
I declare the two fruits of dispute.
Seeing this, one should not dispute,
Desiring the peaceful, non-disputatious ground.”
“Whatever social conventions there are among people,
The wise one does not approach any of them.
Not approaching, what would he do?
Not being satisfied with what is seen or heard.”
“They say that the highest virtue is purification by perception,
With the wind taken in, the breath held.
Here itself is the training, there is purification for him,
The skillful one, led to becoming, is one who has attained.
If he is cut off, virtuous,
He abandons action, and is disappointed.
He aspires, he wishes for purification,

But for one who has no more death and rebirth,

“They declare their own doctrine to be complete,
But they say that the other doctrine is inferior.

original: Evampi viggayha vivādayanti,🔽Sakaṁ sakaṁ sammutimāhu saccaṁ.
analyzed: evam pi viggayha vivādayanti  sakam sakam sammutim āhuḥ sat ca
translated: Thus they argue and dispute,🔽Each saying that their own convention is true.
If one is inferior because of disparaging another,
Then no one would be distinguished in doctrines.
For many declare the doctrine of another
To be inferior, speaking strongly.

analyzed: saddhamma pūjā api na īsam tathā iva
translated: Their worship of the true Dhamma is the same,
As they praise their own doctrines.
All doctrines would be the same,

analyzed: suddhī hi na isam paccattam eva
translated: For their purity is only in themselves.
The brahmin has nothing to do with another’s doctrine,
He would be sure of the Dhamma in himself;
Therefore he has gone beyond the disputes,
For he sees no other Dhamma as supreme.
“I know and see, and it is just so,”
Some reckon their purity by their view.
If he sees, what is the use of that to him?
Having gone beyond, they declare purity by another.
A man who sees sees name-and-form;
Having seen, he will know these very things.

original: Kāmaṁ bahuṁ passatu appakaṁ vā,🔽Na hi tena suddhiṁ kusalā vadanti.

He does not side with those who dispute;
He is peaceful, indifferent to the peaceful and the violent,
He is helpful, as if he were holding his nose.
Having abandoned the old taints and not producing new ones,
He is not a slave to sense pleasures nor is he a nihilist;
